questions.question: The World Health Organization (WHO) has defined blindness as a condition where the level of visual acuity is below
questions.explanation: as visual acuity less than 3/60. It indicates severe impairment of vision, where the person can only see at a distance of 3 meters or less what a person with normal vision can see clearly at 60 meters. WHO Classification of Visual Impairment The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent". The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment Classification Visual Acuity Mild Distance Vision Impairment Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12 Moderate Distance Vision Impairment Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option D ruled out) Severe Distance Vision Impairment Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A ruled out) Blindness Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B) Near Vision Impairment Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction (Option C ruled out) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no-456-457

questions.question: According to the guidelines of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), what would be the criteria to designate a district as a high priority district based on the prevalence of HIV TB?
questions.explanation: designated as a high-priority district based on the prevalence of HIV among tuberculosis (TB) patients. Specifically, if more than 10% of TB patients are found to be HIV-positive, the district is categorized as a high-priority area for intensified TB-HIV collaborative activities. Reference: https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/Sankalak_Report_1.pdf

questions.question: Which disease is targeted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program, with the insect depicted below acting as the vector?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Japanese encephalitis: The insect shown in the figure above is Culex mosquito which is the vector for Japanese encephalitis. Japanese encephalitis is a viral disease that affects the brain and is transmitted by infected mosquitoes, primarily Culex species. It is targeted under the National vector-borne disease control programs in regions where the disease is endemic. National vector-borne disease control program (NVBDCP): Launched: 2002. Includes all vector-borne diseases: Vector Disease Anopheles Malaria Aedes Dengue & chikungunya Culex Japanese encephalitis: Culex quinquefasciatus/ Culex fatigans Filariasis: Culex tritaeniorhynchus, Culex vishnui Sandfly Kala-azar Images for adult mosquitoes: Anopheles Aedes Culex Mansonoides

questions.question: In the Ayushman Bharat scheme, what is the annual health insurance coverage offered to a qualifying family?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - 5 lakhs per family per year: In the Ayushman Bharat scheme , also known as Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), the health insurance package provided for an eligible family is 5 lakhs per family per year . This means that eligible families can avail medical treatment and hospitalization services up to a maximum coverage of 5 lakhs (Indian Rupees) per year. Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana. Launched in 2018 Aim: To achieve Universal Health Coverage in India. It is a flexible scheme. It is not rigid or mandatory for all states to follow. The States can opt to choose. Private Hospitals that have up to 10 beds can provide services under Ayushman Bharat Scheme. It comes under the National Health Protection Scheme Modi Care. Provides insurance coverage - 5 lakh per family, per year. There is no restriction on number of family members. Reference: https://nha.gov.in/PM-JAY

questions.question: Which organization is not involved in providing funding for India's national TB program?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - UNICEF The World Bank, The Global Fund, and Domestic Budgetary Sources are the main funding sources used to purchase anti-tuberculosis medications, tools like microscopes, and diagnostics like CBNAAT cartridges for this programme. Through funding from DBS and the World Bank, the Central Medical Services Society (CMSS), an independent and autonomous organisation under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, purchases the medicines and other supplies. The Global Drug Facility, which is run and maintained by the United Nations Office for Project Services, uses The Global Fund. Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) to Control TB Aim- to eliminate TB by 2030. Target- set by WHO To reduce mortality of TB by 90%. (Option B) To reduce incidence of TB by 80%. (Option D) Global targets under SDG : To reach 90% of all people with TB. To reach 90% of all key populations (Slum dwellers, prisoners, difficult to reach, occupational exposures-silicosis). To achieve 90% treatment. End TB Launched by WHO in 2015. Frameline- 2015- 2035 Aim- Eliminate TB by 2035. (Option A) Target- 95-90-0 Reduce mortality of TB by 95% Reduce incidence of TB by 90% Zero out of pocket expenditure - Government should look after the treatment. Stop TB It was in alignment with Millennium development goals. Target: To reduce mortality & incidence of TB by 50%. (Option C) And Eliminate TB by 2050.

questions.question: Which antigen is present in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine?
questions.explanation: the hepatitis B virus (HBV), which is known as HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen). This antigen is a protein component of the viral envelope and is produced using recombinant DNA technology. It is the major antigen responsible for inducing an immune response against HBV. Incorrect Options: HbeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) (Option A): This antigen is a marker of active viral replication in individuals infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is not a component of the hepatitis B subunit vaccine. HbcAg (Hepatitis B core antigen) (Option C): This antigen is the inner core protein of the hepatitis B virus. It is not included in the hepatitis B subunit vaccine. HBV DNA (Hepatitis B virus DNA) (Option D): HBV DNA is the genetic material of the hepatitis B virus. It is not a component of the hepatitis B subunit vaccine. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 472

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the Pentavalent vaccine?

options.A: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
options.C: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine
options.D: Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.explanation: pentavalent vaccine includes the following components: Diphtheria Tetanus HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) Haemophilus influenza B (Hib) Pertussis (Whooping Cough) The pentavalent vaccine combines these five components into a single formulation to provide protection against these diseases. Incorrect Options: Option A - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio: This option is incorrect because it includes "Injectable Polio" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine. Option B - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Typhoid, HBV, Hib: This option is incorrect because it includes "Typhoid" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine. Option C - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine: This option is incorrect because it includes the "Pneumococcal vaccine" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine. Reference: Bairwa M, Pilania M, Rajput M, Khanna P, Kumar N, Nagar M, Chawla S. Pentavalent vaccine: a major breakthrough in India's Universal Immunization Program. Hum Vaccin Immunother. 2012 Sep;8(9):1314-6. doi: 10.4161/hv.20651. Epub 2012 Aug 16. PMID: 22894968; PMCID: PMC3579914.

questions.question: Which vaccine is linked to the risk of intussusception when administered?
questions.explanation: associated with a small risk of intussusception. The association between the Rotavirus vaccine and intussusception was first observed with an earlier version of the vaccine called RotaShield, which was withdrawn from the market in 1999. Subsequent studies on newer rotavirus vaccines, such as RotaTeq and Rotarix, have found a small increased risk of intussusception following vaccination. Incorrect Options: Oral Polio vaccine (Option B): OPV is used to protect against polio and has not been found to have a significant association with intussusception. Adenovirus vaccine (Option C): Intussusception is not a known side effect or risk associated with the administration of Adenovirus vaccines. Measles vaccine (Option D): The Measles vaccine is not associated with an increased risk of intussusception. Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25, page no: 213,222, 235, 239,250

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is not included in the RBSK screening?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma The RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram) screening program is a government initiative in India aimed at identifying and providing early intervention for various health conditions in children up to the age of 18 years. The diseases screened under RBSK include conditions like congenital cataract , retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) , and Vitamin A deficiency . However, congenital glaucoma is not part of the routine screening under RBSK. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK): Aspect Details Program Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) Launched 2013 under the National Health Mission Objective Improve child health through early identification, screening, and management of health conditions among children aged 0 to 18 years Target Conditions (4Ds) Defects at Birth : Examples include cleft lip/palate, Down syndrome Diseases : Examples include rheumatic heart disease Deficiencies : Examples include anemia, Vitamin A deficiency Developmental Delays including Disabilities Screening Teams Mobile health teams comprising a medical officer, staff nurse, and pharmacist Screening Locations Schools, Anganwadi centers, and homes Referral System District Early Intervention Centers (DEICs) for further management Significance Improves early detection and management of child health issues, reducing morbidity and enhancing quality of life Congenital cataract (Option A) : This condition is included in the RBSK screening, as it is an important cause of preventable blindness in children. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) (Option C) : ROP is included in the screening, as it is a major cause of visual impairment in premature infants. Vitamin A deficiency (Option D) : This is also part of the RBSK screening, as it can lead to blindness and other health complications. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11155784/

questions.question: Which of the following populations is not included in the HIV sentinel surveillance?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - STD clinic attendees. HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS) is designed to track the trends of HIV prevalence in different population groups. However, STD clinic attendees are not specifically included in the sentinel surveillance system in most cases. This is because these individuals are already considered a part of the high-risk population, and their data may overlap with other more defined high-risk groups, such as female sex workers and men who have sex with men . HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS) : Category Details Objective Monitor trends in HIV prevalence, guide public health interventions, and identify high-risk populations. Sentinel Sites Specific locations for surveillance, including antenatal clinics, STD clinics, and high-risk community settings. Populations Included Antenatal Women : To estimate HIV prevalence in the general population. High-Risk Groups : Female sex workers (FSWs), men who have sex with men (MSM), injecting drug users (IDUs). Bridge Populations : Truck drivers, single male migrants. Data Collected HIV Prevalence : Percentage of individuals in the group who are HIV-positive. Demographic Information : Age, gender, occupation, etc. Risk Behavior : Sexual behavior, drug use, and other HIV transmission risk factors. Key Features Regular blood sample collection. HIV testing conducted in sentinel sites. Exclusions STD clinic attendees may not be included as their data overlaps with other high-risk groups. Importance Tracks HIV trends over time. Guides the allocation of resources. Helps design targeted prevention programs for at-risk populations. Single male migrants (Option A) : They are often at higher risk due to mobility and exposure to multiple sexual partners. Truck drivers (Option B) : A high-risk group due to frequent travel and potential for high-risk sexual behavior. Antenatal women (Option D) : Provide important data on the general population and mother-to-child transmission. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2629522/

questions.question: Which statement accurately describes the Nikshay Poshan Yojana program?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rs 500 is given per month Explanation: The Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to provide nutritional support to individuals undergoing treatment for Tuberculosis (TB) . The program aims to improve the nutritional status of TB patients, as proper nutrition is essential for effective treatment and recovery. Under this scheme: Rs 500 is provided monthly to TB patients as nutritional support to help them adhere to their treatment and improve overall health. Rs 500 is given per week (Option A) : This is incorrect because the scheme provides Rs 500 per month , not weekly. Mid-day meals are given (Option C) : This is not part of the Nikshay Poshan Yojana. The program provides financial support for nutrition, but not direct meal distribution. Dietary advice is given (Option D) : While nutrition is a component, the primary focus of the scheme is financial support for food, not direct dietary counseling. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11265306/

questions.question: As a medical officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC), what would be your recommendation for mass prophylaxis/treatment of anemia?

options.A: FeS04 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12 Explanation: As a medical officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC) , for mass prophylaxis or treatment of anemia , the most common approach would include a combination of iron (to treat iron deficiency anemia), along with vitamin C (to enhance iron absorption), folate (for folate deficiency), and vitamin B12 (for vitamin B12 deficiency). This combination is effective for treating nutritional anemia and anemia due to multiple deficiencies in populations, particularly in rural or underserved areas. FeSO4 (Ferrous sulfate) is a commonly used form of oral iron . Vitamin C enhances the absorption of iron. Folate and Vitamin B12 address deficiencies that can contribute to anemia, particularly megaloblastic anemia Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose (Option B) : This is an oral iron preparation , but it's typically used when iron sulfate is not tolerated due to gastrointestinal side effects. However, it may not be the first choice for mass prophylaxis. Ferrous fumarate (Option C) : Another form of oral iron , but the inclusion of vitamins C, B12, and folate in Option A makes it a more comprehensive approach. Inj. iron sucrose (Option D) : This is an injectable iron preparation used for patients who cannot tolerate oral iron or have severe iron deficiency anemia. However, it is not typically used for mass prophylaxis at the PHC level due to its cost and the need for trained personnel to administer injections. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 710, 732, 733

questions.question: Identify the logo?
questions.explanation: Options: Options B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.question: Identify the given logo below?
questions.explanation: is the national standards body of India. It operates under the Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution, Government of India. The logo represents the organization's commitment to setting and promoting standards for products, processes, and services in India. LOGO DESCRIPTION (A) Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) Headquarters: New Delhi Ministry: Health and Family Welfare Provides national food standards for products Adopts standards from CODEX ALIMENTARIUS by WHO and FAO (WHO Headquarters: Geneva; FAO Headquarters: Rome) Recently launched the Eat Right Campaign (B) Bureau of Indian Standards Ministry: Ministry of Consumer affairs PFA (Prevention of Food Adulteration) provides the Minimum quality of food products. BIS provides quality above the minimum standards of food products. (C) Fruit Product/Process Order. The Ministry of Food Processing Industries has created an online system for licensing and monitoring all activities related to the enforcement and administration of FPO. Regulates the quality of tinned fruit juices and tinned fruit cans. (D) This is administered by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection (DMI) under the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare for agricultural products. AGMARK is a certification mark indicating that agricultural produce meets a grade standard specified by DMI

questions.question: A researcher who was studying on plasmodium species decided to visit the malaria-endemic place in Odisha after 2 days to do his clinical study for 5 weeks. Which of the following drugs need to be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.explanation: malaria prophylaxis is Doxycycline 100mg daily. Chemoprophylaxis of malaria: Short-term prophylaxis Long-term prophylaxis Duration of Rx < 6 weeks > 6 weeks DOC Doxycycline 100 mg daily (Option C) Mefloquine 250 mg weekly (Option B ruled out) Prophylaxis period Before travel 1-2 days 2-3 weeks After travel 4 weeks 4 weeks Contraindications of mefloquine: History of convulsions. Neuropsychiatric illness. Cardiac conditions. Other drugs for short-term prophylaxis: Chloroquine: 100 mg or 150 mg tablets. 300 mg (3 tablets of 100 mg or 2 tablets of 150 mg), once a week, on the same day each week. (Or) One tablet of 100 mg daily for 6 days per week. Proguanil: 200 mg, 2 tablets once a day. Artesunate (Option A): It is typically used to treat malaria. This option is incorrect. Chloramphenicol (Option D): It is an antibiotic that is not typically used for malaria prophylaxis. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 312,313 Diagnosis and Treatment of Malaria

questions.question: What is the quickest method for laboratory diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: can detect the genetic material (DNA) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes TB. It is a highly sensitive and specific test that can provide rapid results. Diagnostic Modality Description Usage Sputum Smear Microscopy (Option B ruled out) Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings. Chest X-ray Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB. Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis. TruNAAT/CBNAAT (Option A) Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance. Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results. Line Probe Assay (LPA) Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid). Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis. Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein. Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis. Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs) Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens. Used for detecting latent TB infection Sputum Culture (Option C ruled out) Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility. Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results. Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST) Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs. Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases. Radiometric BACTEC method (Option D): It offers faster detection compared to conventional culture methods but still requires several weeks to obtain results. This option is incorrect. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th edition Pg 214-230

questions.question: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the program whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except: transmission season. during the entire transmission season.

options.A: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire
options.B: Long lasting insecticide nest (LLIN) should be provided in areas with annual parasite Index 25.
options.C: Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
options.D: In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection

questions.explanation: spraying (IRS) is considered an effective vector control measure, including in rural areas. IRS involves spraying insecticides on the interior walls of houses to kill mosquitoes and reduce their population. It is an important component of integrated malaria control programs. National vector-borne disease control program (NVBDCP): Launched: 2002. Includes all vector-borne diseases: Vector Disease Anopheles Malaria Aedes Dengue & chikungunya Culex Japanese encephalitis: Culex quinquefasciatus/ Culex fatigans Filariasis: Culex tritaeniorhynchus, Culex vishnui Sandfly Kala-azar Indoor residual spray (IRS): Chemicals used: DDT 50% WP: Insecticide of choice Malathion 25% Synthetic pyrethroids: Deltamethrin and Cyfluthrin IRS with insecticides when API >2 : 2 rounds of DDT (1gm/m 2 ) at a 6-week interval during the transmission season (Option A ruled out) ↓ If refractory: ADD malathion, 3 rounds of Malathion (2gm/m 2 ) at 6-week intervals. (Option D ruled out) ↓ If still refractory: ADD 2 rounds of a synthetic pyrethroid (0.25gm/m 2 ) at 6-week intervals. Note: Long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLIN) covers the population living in areas where API > 5. Long-Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs) are mosquito nets treated with insecticides that are designed to retain their effectiveness for an extended period, typically up to 3 years , even after repeated washing. They are a critical tool in NVBDCP to fight against

questions.question: Which of the following diseases are included in the scheme, which has the logo as given below?
questions.explanation: is of the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS). Under this programme, the included diseases are CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, and Stroke. The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) is explicitly described as an integrated program. It combines efforts to address cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke, making it the most suitable program with a logo reflecting this integrated approach. Component Initiatives New Initiatives under NPCDCS Intervention for prevention and control of Rheumatic Heart Disease under NPCDCS and Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK). Integration of AYUSH with NPCDCS. Integration of RNTCP with NPCDCS to articulate a national strategy for management of TB and diabetes comorbidities in India. Cancer Component under NPCDCS Cancer Services under NPCDCS: Providing common diagnostic services, basic surgery, chemotherapy, and palliative care for cancer patients at 100 district hospitals. Supporting each district with chemotherapy drugs for 100 patients, establishing day-care chemotherapy facilities, and providing facilities for laboratory investigations, including mammography. Offering home-based palliative care for chronic and progressive cancer patients in 100 districts. Designating State Cancer Institutes (SCIs) as apex

questions.question: Which organization is involved in intersectoral coordination in the integrated child development services (ICDS)?
questions.explanation: coordination between the ICDS and the NHM. Their coordination is focused on the nutrition of the child and the child's health care. The components of NHM: Goals of NHM: Reduce Infant Mortality Rate to 25/1000 live births Reduce Maternal Mortality Rate to 1/1000 live births Reduce Total Fertility Rate to 2.1 Reduce annual incidence and mortality from TB by half. Reduce prevalence of Leprosy to <1/10000 population and incidence to zero in all districts Annual malaria incidence to < 1/1000. <1% microfilaria prevalence in all districts. Eliminate kala-azar by 2015 Components of RMNCAH+N: NACO (Option B): NACO is the National AIDS Control organization and it does not work in coordination with ICDS. NLEP (Option C): NLEP is the National Leprosy Eradication Program and it does not work in coordination with ICDS. UNDP (Option D): UNDP is the United Nations development program and it does not work in coordination with ICDS.

questions.question: The full form of the Urban HEART programme is:

options.A: Urban health equity assessment and response tool
options.B: Urban health evaluation assessment and response tool
options.C: Urban health equity assessment and response technique
options.D: Urban health evaluation assessment and response technique

questions.explanation: a tool developed by WHO that is designed to address health inequities in urban areas. It helps policymakers identify disparities, assess their causes, and implement strategies to improve health outcomes for disadvantaged populations. Health of individuals varies due to variation in genetic and constitutional variations. Older people tend to be sicker than younger people, because of the natural ageing process. These turn difference in health into an inequity in health. Reference: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241500142

questions.question: Please recognize the logo displayed in the provided image
questions.explanation: is under the National AIDS Control Programme. Suraksha Clinic (previously Designated STI/RTI Clinics) is an STI/RTI clinic chain. The National AIDS Control Organisation founded these clinics to provide improved healthcare and to combat HIV/AIDS in India.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for DOTS?

options.B: Every patient is given the same treatment
options.C: Streptomycin is given to all the patients

questions.explanation: strategy for the treatment of tuberculosis (TB). One of the key principles of DOTS is that treatment is administered under direct supervision by a healthcare provider or trained observer. This ensures that patients adhere to the prescribed treatment regimen and complete the full course of treatment, which is essential for successful TB treatment and prevention of drug resistance. 99DOTS: A cost-effective method to monitor and improve adherence to TB medication. Anti-TB blister packs are wrapped in envelopes with hidden toll free phone numbers revealed only when doses are dispensed. Patients make a call to the hidden number after taking their medication, confirming dose intake. Reference: 99DOTS Deployments 99 DOTS and MERM boxes | Knowledge Base

questions.question: A' Bacteriologically Confirmed Case' in TB is defined as:
questions.explanation: who has been diagnosed with TB based on the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (the bacteria that causes TB) in their sputum sample. A positive sputum test confirms the presence of TB bacteria, making it an important diagnostic criterion for identifying TB cases. The new NTEP changes in terminologies are as follows:- Category Description Criteria/Features Presumptive TB Case Used in place of TB suspect . Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed. -Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks (Option D ruled out) Clinically Diagnosed TB Case Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB. Used in place of Sputum negative TB case. -Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear - High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features (Option A ruled out) Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case (Option B) Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT. Used in place of Sputum positive TB case. - Positive sputum smear for AFB - Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th edition Pg 210-211

questions.question: What type of blindness does the individual have if their right eye has a visual acuity of 6/60 and their left eye has a visual acuity of 3/60?
questions.explanation: cannot be fully corrected with glasses, contact lenses, medication, or surgery. Individuals with low vision have visual acuity below normal levels but still have some remaining functional vision. In the given scenario, the person's visual acuity is 6/60 in the right eye and 3/60 in the left eye, indicating a severe visual impairment. Incorrect Options Option A: Manifest blindness- Vision 3/60 or just perception of light. It does not accurately describe the person's condition. Option B: Social blindness- Vision 3/60 or Diniution of the field of vision to 10 degrees. It does not accurately describe the person's condition. Option D: Absence of blindness- This option is incorrect because the person clearly has a visual impairment. The visual acuity measurements indicate a significant reduction in vision. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: As part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild to moderate anemia who are less than 34 weeks pregnant are managed with the following treatment approach:

options.A: 2 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets OD
options.B: IV iron sucrose for noncompliance with oral tablets
options.C: 2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.explanation: less than 34 weeks pregnant are generally managed with oral iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets . The typical treatment involves 2 IFA tablets OD (once a day) . IV iron sucrose is usually considered for noncompliant patients who are unable to take oral supplements effectively or when oral supplementation does not improve the condition, but it is not the first-line treatment in cases of mild to moderate anemia. IM ferric carboxy maltose (FCM) is also an alternative but is typically reserved for more severe cases of anemia or in cases where intravenous iron is needed. Therefore, for mild to moderate anemia in pregnant women less than 34 weeks , oral IFA tablets are the standard first-line treatment. The 6x6x6 strategy is related to anemia mukt Bharat. It stands for 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms. 6 INTERVENTIONS 6 STRATEGIES Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation. Deworming. Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping. Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment. Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis. National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit. Intra-ministerial coordination. Strengthening supply chain and logistics. Convergence with other ministries. National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control. Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia. 6 BENEFICIARIES Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose) Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid) Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets) Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days ). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid , is sugar-coated, and red in color. Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid , is sugar-coated, and red in color. Reference: Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797 https://pmposhan.education.gov.in/aboutus.html https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/5x5_matrix_2502.pdf https://wcd.nic.in/kishori-shakti-yojana

questions.question: What does JSSK stand for?
questions.explanation: (JSSK) is a scheme launched by the Government of India to provide free and cashless healthcare services to pregnant women, mothers, and newborns. The program aims to reduce maternal and infant mortality rates by ensuring that all pregnant women and newborns have access to essential healthcare services without financial constraints. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.explanation: leprosy awareness in India, symbolizing hope and the possibility of a future free from leprosy-related stigma and disease. Option C - Meena UNICEF : The Meena campaign, supported by UNICEF, focuses on gender equality and education for girls in South Asia. It is not related to leprosy or the image in question.

questions.question: Which one of the following is NOT included in Ayushman Bharat under school health services?
questions.explanation: monthly, under the Ayushman Bharat scheme to prevent anemia in school-aged children. Incorrect Options: Option A - Providing sanitary pads : This is included under the Ayushman Bharat School Health Program, which aims to promote menstrual hygiene among adolescent girls by providing sanitary pads. Option B - Health check-up/screening : Regular health check-ups and screenings are part of the school health services under Ayushman Bharat to identify and address health issues among school children. Option C - Albendazole provision : Albendazole is provided for deworming under the school health services, targeting the prevention of parasitic infections in children. Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/SH&WP/IEC/Advocacy-Material/Services_provided_under_ SH&WP.pdf https://nhm.hp.gov.in/storage/app/media/uploaded-files/Operational_guidelines_on_School_Health_Pr ogramme_under_Ayushman_Bharat.pdf

questions.question: How much mg of iron and mcg of folic acid should a pregnant woman be given?
questions.explanation: and 500 mcg of folic acid daily is provided to pregnant and lactating women Age Group Iron Dose & Frequency Folic Acid Dose & Frequency Infants (6-59 months) 1 ml IFA syrup (20 mg elemental iron, 100 mcg folic acid) biweekly Included in syrup (100 mcg) biweekly Preschool Children (5-9 years) 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid weekly Included in tablet (400 mcg) weekly Adolescents (10-19 years) 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly Included in tablet (500 mcg) weekly Pregnant & Lactating Women 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily Included in tablet (500 mcg) daily Women of Reproductive Age (15-49 years) 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly Included in tablet (500 mcg) weekly Incorrect Options: Option A, B & D are incorrect Reference: Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) | National Health Mission Tamil Nadu, Department of Health & Family Welfare Govt. of Tamil Nadu, India Operational Guidelines for Weekly IFA Supplementation Programme for the Community Based Intervention Guidelines for Anganwadi Workers

questions.question: The biological method for Mosquito Larva control is done by?
questions.explanation: mosquito larvae, thus helping to reduce the mosquito population in water bodies where they are introduced. They are particularly effective in controlling mosquito larvae in stagnant or slow-moving water bodies like ponds, ditches, and water tanks. This method of biological control is environmentally friendly and sustainable. Additionally, Gambusia fish are easy to rear and maintain, making them a practical and cost-effective solution for mosquito larva control in certain habitats. Anti-larval measures against mosquito larvae: Environmental measures Chemical control Biological control Yield permanent results and source reduction. E.g. Filling drains and ditches. Levelling of ground. Proper drainage of breeding areas. Intermittent irrigation. Changing water alkalinity. Using larvicides E.g. 1. Physical: MLO (Mosquito larvicidal oil): 200L/hectare 2. Chemical: Paris green Temephos (Abate): 200L/hectare 3. IGR (insect growth regulators): Inhibit chitin formation, moulding and adult maturation. Pyriproxyfen and Diflubenzuron Larvivorous Fishes: 1. Gambusia and Poecilia fish 2. Bacillus thuringiensis (used in polluted waters) 3. Toxorhynchites splendens (predator mosquito for Aedes and Anopheles) Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 477-9

questions.question: Check-ups conducted for children aged 9-18 years under Rashtriya Bal Swasthya karyakram is done for every?
questions.explanation: 2013. It relies on early childhood and interventional services. Children between 6-18 years are screened at government schools by a mobile health team at least 2 times a year. RBSK Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram: RBSK Launched in 2013. Relies on early childhood screening and interventional services. Age group 0-6 years- urban or rural slums 6-18 years- government school-going children Screening Secondary level of prevention Screening done for 4Ds: Diseases Defects Deficiencies Developmental delays Screened by Mobile teams and this includes: Medical officers Ayush officers Pharmacists Lab technicians Incorrect Options: Option A, B & C are incorrect Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 529 https://nhm.gov.in/index4.php?lang=1&level=0&linkid=499&lid=773

questions.question: A 49-year-old man came for a follow-up after recently receiving a new diagnosis and treatment initiation. He is counseled about the Axshya project. Which of the following diseases was this patient diagnosed with?
questions.explanation: control efforts in India. It focuses on strengthening TB care and control services, including early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of TB cases. The project includes strategies such as community mobilization, awareness campaigns, and active case finding to reach vulnerable populations and reduce the TB burden. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D: Project Axshya does not deal with any of these diseases. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 472

questions.question: The Anemia Mukt Bharat program aims to address anemia across India through targeted interventions. Which statement accurately describes its administration of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation? months

options.A: IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6
options.B: IFA supplementation is administered solely during pregnancy
options.C: A 100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient
options.D: Administering IFA during the 1st trimester is adequate.

questions.explanation: lactation for up to 6 months lactation for up to 6 months The Anemia Mukt Bharat program includes comprehensive IFA supplementation that begins during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues through lactation for up to 6 months. Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation: 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar coated - pink color. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole tablet 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of Feb of every year) Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole. Pregnant women: starts in 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues through lactation for up to 6 months. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect as IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months.

questions.question: What is the WHO definition of blindness?
questions.explanation: visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. Distance vision impairment (WHO): Mild – visual acuity worse than 6/12 Moderate – visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option C) Severe – visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A) Blindness – visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B) 1/60 (Option D): 1/60 is not the specific cut-off point defined by the WHO for blindness. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 472 https://www.paho.org/en/ topics/visual-health#:~:text=Distance%20vision%20impairment%3A,acuity%20worse%20than%203%2F60

questions.question: Paris green dust is commonly used to kill which of the following?
questions.explanation: used for its larvicidal properties. It is particularly effective in controlling the larvae of mosquitoes, such as Anopheles larvae. Anti-larval measures against mosquito larvae: Environmental measures Chemical control Biological control Yield permanent results and source reduction. E.g. Filling drains and ditches. Levelling of ground. Proper drainage of breeding areas. Intermittent irrigation. Changing water alkalinity. Using larvicides E.g. 1. Physical: MLO (Mosquito larvicidal oil): 200L/hectare 2. Chemical: Paris green Temephos (Abate): 200L/hectare 3. IGR (insect growth regulators): Inhibit chitin formation, moulding and adult maturation. Pyriproxyfen and Diflubenzuron Larvivorous Fishes: 1. Gambusia and Poecilia fish 2. Bacillus thuringiensis (used in polluted waters) 3. Toxorhynchites splendens (predator mosquito for Aedes and Anopheles) Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D : Paris green is not effective against houseflies, bedbugs, and cockroaches. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 477-479

questions.question: Which of the following is correct regarding Ayushman Bharat scheme?

options.A: Rs 5 lakh/per family per year is given
options.B: Rs 10 lakh/per family per year is given
options.C: Rs 6 lakh/per family per year is given
options.D: Rs 2 lakh/per family per year is given

questions.explanation: Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), is a health insurance scheme launched by the Government of India. The scheme aims to provide financial protection to economically vulnerable families by offering health insurance coverage for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. Incorrect Options: Option B - Rs 10 lakh/per family per year: It is not the correct amount provided by the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct amount is Rs 5 lakh. Option C - Rs 6 lakh/per family per year: It is not the correct amount provided by the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct amount is Rs 5 lakh. Option D - Rs 2 lakh/per family per year: It is not the correct amount provided by the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct amount is Rs 5 lakh.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about the National Program for Control Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCB and VI)?

options.A: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to the base hospital
options.B: To perform more small incision cataract surgeries
options.C: To perform surgeries in rural areas with makeshift hospitals/OTs
options.D: To perform surgeries in fixed facilities by shifting patients from rural areas.

questions.explanation: the National Program for Control Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCB and VI) due to concerns related to follow-up issues. Proposed structure for Vision 2020, NPCB: Tier Number of Units Population Norms Components Centres of Excellence 20 1/50 million Professional Leadership Strategy development Continued Medical Education (CME) Laying of standards and quality assurance Research Training Centres 200 1/5 million Tertiary eye care including retinal surgery, corneal transplantation, glaucoma surgery, etc. Training and CME Service Centres 2000 1/500000 Cataract Surgery Other common eye surgeries Facilities for refraction Referral services Vision Centres 20,000 1/50000 Refraction and prescription of glasses Primary eye care School eye screening programme Screening and referral services Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg 505

questions.question: School health program is under:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) PHC Explanation: The School Health Program in India is typically managed and implemented under Primary Health Centres (PHCs) . These centers provide basic healthcare services to communities, including children in schools, through regular health check-ups, immunizations, and health education. The PHCs serve as the main hub for delivering health services to the school-aged population. CHC (Option B): is incorrect because Community Health Centres (CHCs) focus on more specialized and advanced healthcare services than PHCs. They are not the primary location for managing the School Health Program. DH (Option C): is incorrect because District Hospitals (DH) focus on providing specialized healthcare and emergency services rather than delivering primary health services in schools. Health and Wellness Centres (Option D): While Health and Wellness Centres are part of the National Health Mission and offer comprehensive healthcare services, the School Health Program is more closely associated with PHCs for primary healthcare services in the school setting. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 663- 667.

questions.question: In the context of a national public health initiative aimed at addressing anemia, which of the following programs follows the "6x6x6 strategy"?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anemia Mukt Bharat Explanation: The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program, launched by the Government of India, aims to reduce anemia among women, children, and adolescents. The "6x6x6 strategy" refers to a set of actions designed to address anemia, focusing on: 6 target age groups (children aged 6-59 months, adolescent girls, pregnant women, lactating mothers, women of reproductive age, and men) 6 interventions (Iron and Folic Acid supplementation, deworming, malaria control, nutrition improvement, managing hemorrhage during childbirth, and controlling hookworm) 6 delivery platforms (school-based programs, anganwadis, health centers, etc.) Poshan Abhiyan (Option B): is incorrect because the Poshan Abhiyan (National Nutrition Mission) focuses on improving the nutritional status of children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers but does not specifically follow the "6x6x6 strategy" related to anemia. Kishori Shakti Yojana (Option C): is incorrect because the Kishori Shakti Yojana focuses on the empowerment of adolescent girls, providing them with life skills training, but it does not follow the "6x6x6 strategy" for addressing anemia. None of these (Option D): is incorrect because Anemia Mukt Bharat (Option A) clearly follows the "6x6x6 strategy" for anemia control. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 281

questions.question: Which government program aims to provide health checkups and services for children aged 0-18, including a focus on those not attending school?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram Explanation: The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram (RBSK) is a government initiative aimed at providing health checkups and services to children aged 0-18 years , including those who are not attending school . The program focuses on identifying and addressing health issues, such as congenital abnormalities, disabilities, and malnutrition, ensuring early intervention and appropriate treatment. Janani Suraksha Yojna (Option B): is incorrect because Janani Suraksha Yojna primarily focuses on providing safe motherhood, promoting institutional deliveries, and reducing maternal and neonatal mortality, rather than addressing the health needs of children aged 0-18 years. Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (Option C): is incorrect because Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram focuses on ensuring newborn survival by providing immediate care at the time of birth and focusing on newborn health rather than a comprehensive child health program for the 0-18 age group. Mid Day Meal Program (Option D): is incorrect because the Mid Day Meal Program focuses on providing nutritious meals to children in schools, particularly to promote enrollment and retention, and does not cover comprehensive health checkups and services for children outside of school. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 506, 507 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4586976/

questions.question: A 10-year-old school-going girl came for a health checkup. Her Hb is 9 g/dL. Which of the following government programs is likely to provide significant benefit to her health?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) Explanation: RBSK is a comprehensive program under the National Health Mission that focuses on early identification and intervention for children aged 0-18 years, targeting deficiencies such as anemia, developmental delays, and diseases. It supports the health and well-being of school-going children like the one described. Janani Suraksha Yojana (Option B) : is incorrect because this scheme focuses on promoting institutional deliveries and maternal health benefits rather than addressing child health and anemia in school-going children. Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option C) : is incorrect because it primarily provides financial support to pregnant and lactating mothers for better nutrition and postnatal care, not directly targeting school children. Navjat Shishu Karyakram Yojana (Option D) : is incorrect because it emphasizes newborn care and resuscitation in healthcare settings, not for health checkups of school-going children. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 506, 507

questions.question: The proposal to control malaria in towns named as Urban Malaria Scheme. According to Urban Malaria Scheme, Which of the following is not true?

options.C: Scheme is not based on blood examination
options.D: Towns having a population more than 10,000

questions.explanation: malaria in towns and cities. One of the criteria for implementing the scheme is a slide positivity rate (SPR) of more than 5% but less than or equal to 10%. Therefore, the statement "Slide positivity rate more than 10%" is not true. Incorrect Options: Option A - SPR between 5% and 10%: This range is a valid criterion for implementing the Urban Malaria Scheme. Option C - Scheme is not based on blood examination : The scheme is not based on the blood examination slide rate but on the slide positivity rate. Option D - Towns having a population more than 10,000: The scheme can be implemented in towns with a population more than 10,000. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: A 30-year-old male truck driver visited to the clinic with fever, skin rash, swollen glands and fatigue. The physician referred him to suraksha clinic. Which among the following is included in provision of services at Suraksha Clinic ?
questions.explanation: services related to reproductive and sexual health. RTI (Reproductive Tract Infection) and STI (Sexually Transmitted Infection) services are included in the range of services offered at the Suraksha Clinic. Incorrect Options: Option A - Immunization services: Suraksha Clinic primarily focuses on reproductive and sexual health services, and immunization services are not typically provided in this context. Option B - Blood transfusion safety services: Suraksha Clinic does not specifically provide blood transfusion safety services. Option D - Diarrhea control services: Diarrhea control services are not typically part of the services offered at the Suraksha Clinic. Reference: .

questions.question: Ujjawala scheme is for prevention of?
questions.explanation: preventing and combating human trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. It focuses on rescuing and rehabilitating victims of trafficking, providing them with support services, and raising awareness about the issue. Incorrect Options: Option A - Child abuse: While the Ujjawala scheme indirectly addresses the prevention of child abuse through its efforts to combat child trafficking, it specifically focuses on trafficking-related issues. Option C - Child labour: The Ujjawala scheme primarily targets child trafficking rather than child labor. Option D - Child marriage: Child marriage is not the main focus of the Ujjawala scheme; it primarily addresses human trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Peripheral blood smear sample for malaria is done by?
questions.explanation: obtained by a laboratory technician. These technicians are trained and skilled in collecting blood samples and preparing blood smears for microscopic examination to detect the presence of malaria parasites. Incorrect Options: Option A, B & C are not typically responsible for obtaining peripheral blood smear samples for malaria. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: In a rural village , a government school conducted a comprehensive health check-up for all its students. According to Vision 2020 , which of the following centre will the teacher refer school children to in order to check their visual acuity?
questions.explanation: blindness, one of the strategies is to provide accessible eye care services. Vision centers are established to provide primary eye care, including vision testing and provision of eyeglasses, in areas where access to eye care is limited. Therefore, the teacher would refer school children to a vision center to check their visual acuity. Incorrect Options: Option A - Service center: The term "service center" is general and does not specifically relate to eye care or vision testing. Option B - Training center: Training centers are focused on providing education and training rather than direct provision of eye care services. Option C - Center for excellence: Centers of excellence generally refer to specialized institutions that excel in a specific field. While they may provide advanced eye care services, they are not typically involved in routine vision testing in schools. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which group is excluded from targeted interventions, a specific set of services and interventions provided to individuals in the population who are at high risk of or have reported high risk of HIV?
questions.explanation: package of interventions and services designed to reach and address the needs of populations at high risk of HIV or those who have reported a high risk of HIV. Doctors and nurses are not high-risk group but suffer accidental injuries. Incorrect Options: Option A - Migrant labourers: Migrant labourers, who often move across regions or countries for work, are considered a high-risk group due to factors such as mobility, separation from families, and engagement in risky behaviors. Option B - Street children: Street children, who may lack stable housing and support systems, are vulnerable to various health risks, including HIV infection. Option C - Long-distance truckers: Long-distance truckers, who frequently travel across different regions or countries as part of their occupation, are at increased risk of HIV. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the CD4 cut off for initiating Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) in the treatment of AIDS?
questions.explanation: (ART) is not solely based on a specific CD4 cell count cut-off. The decision to start ART depends on various factors, including clinical symptoms, CD4 count, viral load, and the individual's overall health. Incorrect Options: Option A - 200 : This CD4 cut-off was previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count. Option B - 350 : This CD4 cut-off was also previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count. Option C - 500: This CD4 cut-off was previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count. Reference: 1)Notes, 2) Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: Under which program does the improvement of labor room quality fall in?
questions.explanation: rooms in healthcare facilities. It is an initiative of the Government of India that aims to enhance the safety and quality of care provided during childbirth. The program focuses on ensuring respectful maternity care, infection prevention and control, effective communication, and skilled birth attendance. Incorrect Options: Option B - Ayushman Bharat: Ayushman Bharat is a national health protection scheme “in India that aims to provide financial protection and access to quality healthcare to vulnerable population” with “that” focuses on health insurance coverage and primary healthcare services but does not specifically address the improvement of labor room quality. Option C - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram is a government program that promotes safe delivery and postnatal care, it does not specifically address the improvement of labor room quality. Option D - Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan focuses on ensuring comprehensive and quality antenatal check-ups but does not specifically focus on improving labor room quality. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the name of the recently introduced online software by the Indian government, as part of the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP), for the purpose of monitoring patients with tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: specifically designed for the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program in India. It facilitates the tracking of TB patients, monitors their treatment progress, manages drug supply, and provides real-time data for better decision-making and planning. Incorrect Options: Option B - NISCHAY: NISCHAY is not associated with the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program or TB patient monitoring. Option C - E-DOTS: While e-DOTS is a term associated with the use of electronic DOTS for TB treatment, it is not the specific software launched under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program in India. Option D - NIKUSTH: NIKUSTH is not a recognized software or system related to the monitoring of TB patients under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: As per IMNCI guidelines, a diagnosis of pneumonia is made in a 6-month-old infant when the child exhibits rapid breathing with a respiratory rate exceeding:
questions.explanation: pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than 50 breaths per minute. Incorrect Options: Option A, B & C are incorrect Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following criteria would you utilize to evaluate the effectiveness of the malaria surveillance system implemented by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.explanation: population at risk of malaria who have undergone blood examination for malaria parasites. It indicates the coverage of the population undergoing diagnostic testing for malaria and is used to assess the efficiency of the surveillance system. Incorrect Options: Option A - Annual Parasite Index (API): The API is used to measure the incidence or burden of malaria in a population. Option C - Slide Positivity Rate (SPR): The SPR provides information about the proportion of individuals tested who have confirmed malaria infection. Option D - Slide Falciparum Rate (SFR): The SFR specifically focuses on the prevalence of P. falciparum infection among tested individuals. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Under Vision 2020, a disease that was added later in India
questions.explanation: World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020. While glaucoma is a significant cause of blindness globally, it was added later in India's Vision 2020 initiative. This highlights the growing recognition of the importance of early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of glaucoma to prevent vision loss. Incorrect Options: Option A - Cataract: Cataract has been a significant focus of Vision 2020 from the beginning. Cataract is the leading cause of blindness worldwide, including in India. Option B - Childhood blindness: Childhood blindness has also been an important focus of Vision 2020. Option D - Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is another eye condition that has been a focus of the Vision 2020 program. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: NITI AAYOG represents?
questions.explanation: Transforming India) is a policy Think Tank of the Government of India. It was established in 2015 to replace the Planning Commission and provide strategic and policy inputs across various sectors of the economy. NITI Aayog's main objective is to foster sustainable development and facilitate cooperative federalism by promoting the involvement of states in the economic decision-making process. Incorrect Options: Option A - Newer Initiative Transforming India: NITI Aayog is not specifically focused on newer initiatives but rather on transforming India as a whole. Option B - Nutrition Intake to India: NITI Aayog's mandate extends beyond nutrition intake and encompasses a broader range of policy areas. Option D - National Institute for Technical India: NITI Aayog is not solely focused on nutrition or functioning as an institute dedicated to nutrition in India. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of Urban health care delivery system?
questions.explanation: subcenter is not a part of it. Subcenters are primarily a component of rural healthcare infrastructure. They are the first level of contact between the rural population and the medical officer, providing essential healthcare services at the grassroots level. Incorrect Options: Option A - PHC (Primary Health Center): These are health facilities designed to provide basic healthcare services to the population in urban as well as rural areas.. Option B - CHC (Community Health Center): CHCs are higher-level health facilities that are responsible for providing comprehensive healthcare services to a larger population, typically covering a group of PHCs. Option C - Swasthya chowki: Swasthya chowki is a part of the urban health care system at the primary level. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 10-year-old school-going girl came for a health checkup. Her Hb is 9 g/dL. Which of the following government programs is likely to provide significant benefit to her health?
questions.explanation: is a key government initiative in India focusing on children's health (0-18 years). It conducts health screenings at schools and anganwadi centers to detect issues like anemia, malnutrition, and developmental delays early. The program offers interventions, referrals, and health education to ensure children receive timely care and support, promoting their overall well-being. Incorrect Options: Option B - Janani Suraksha Yojana: It is a program that focuses on promoting institutional deliveries and providing financial assistance to pregnant women for giving birth in health facilities. Option C - Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana: PMMVY is a maternity benefit program providing partial compensation for the wage loss in terms of cash incentives so that the pregnant woman can take adequate rest before and after delivery. It targets pregnant and lactating mothers, not school-aged children. Option D - Navjat Shishu Karyakram Yojna: (Newborn and Child Health Program) focuses on the health and well-being of newborns and infants. It includes services like immunization, growth monitoring, and counseling for mothers. While it's relevant for young children, it may not directly address the presented situation of a 10-year-old girl with low hemoglobin levels. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: In the context of a national public health initiative aimed at addressing anemia, which of the following program follows the "6x6x6 strategy" ?
questions.explanation: Bharat (AMB) initiative. This initiative is a national public health program in India aimed at combating anemia. The "6x6x6 strategy" focuses on six interventions in six target beneficiary groups over six years to reduce anemia prevalence by three percentage points per year. Incorrect Options: Option B - Poshan Abhiyan (National Nutrition Mission): It is a multi-ministerial convergence mission that aims to address malnutrition, including anemia,. While it addresses anemia, it does not specifically follow the "6x6x6 strategy." Option C - Kishori Shakti Yojana: It addresses various issues faced by adolescent girls but does not directly relate to the "6x6x6 strategy." Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: School health program is under
questions.explanation: purview of Primary Health Centres. PHCs are the most basic units of the public health system in many countries and they focus on providing primary healthcare services to the community. School health programs fall within their scope as they address the health needs of school-age children, ensuring their well-being and promoting healthy habits. Incorrect Options: Option B - CHC (Community Health Centre): CHCs are a step above PHCs and offer more comprehensive healthcare services to a larger catchment area. Option C - DH (District Hospital): While they might have a role in coordinating and overseeing certain public health initiatives, school health programs are usually implemented at a more grassroots level. Option D - Health and Wellness Centres: While they promote a comprehensive approach to healthcare, school health programs might not always be directly managed by these centers Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which government program aims to provide health checkups and services for children aged 0-18, including a focus on those not attending school?
questions.explanation: (RBSK) involves screening of children from birth to 18 years of age for 4 Ds- Defects at birth, Diseases, Deficiencies and Development delays, spanning 32 common health conditions for early detection and free treatment and management, including surgeries at tertiary level Incorrect Options: Option B - Janani Suraksha Yojna: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a government program that focuses on promoting institutional deliveries by providing financial assistance to pregnant women. Option C - Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram: Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (NSSK) is another program that aims to provide care to newborns and ensure their survival during the first 28 days of life. Option D - Mid day meal program: The Mid Day Meal Program is a school-based initiative that provides nutritious meals to schoolchildren to enhance their nutritional status and encourage school attendance. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following healthcare providers is not working at the village level ?
questions.explanation: sub-centre level to provide basic healthcare services to the community. Incorrect Options: Option B - AWW: AWW (Anganwadi Worker) is a community-level healthcare worker under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Scheme. Option C - TBA: TBA (Traditional Birth Attendant) is a community-level healthcare provider who provides basic maternal healthcare services and attends to normal deliveries. Option D - ASHA: ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) is a community-level healthcare provider who works under the National Health Mission (NHM) to provide basic healthcare services. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A baby presents for a routine examination in the outpatient department. A growth chart is utilized to record the baby's weight, which falls within the 85th - 95th percentile range. What is the present condition of the child?

options.D: Interpretation cannot be made without BMI

questions.explanation: over time. These charts provide a range of values called percentiles, which indicate how a child's measurements compare to those of other children of the same age and sex. The 85th-95th percentile range is considered overweight, indicating that the child is heavier than 85-95% of children of the same age and sex. Incorrect Options: Option A - Obesity: While being overweight is a risk factor for obesity, it is not the same as obesity. Option B - SAM: Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is typically diagnosed based on clinical criteria, including a low weight-for-height ratio and nutritional edema. Option D - Interpretation cannot be made without BMI: This option is irrelavent. As Body mass index (BMI) better indicates body fat percentage than growth charts alone. Reference: Prepladder Notes
